verses.text: Love righteousness, you who judge the earth; think of the Lord with honesty, and seek him with a sincere heart.
verses.comment: ‘Righteousness’ here is tied to both just living and right judgment. The call to seek God with sincerity echoes themes in Psalms and Isaiah about approaching God authentically.

verses.text: Because he is found by those who do not put him to the test, and is revealed to those who do not distrust him.
verses.comment: The verse teaches that genuine faith—without skepticism—leads to true knowledge of God, a recurring theme in the New Testament (Matt. 7:7) and Psalms.

verses.text: For deceitful thoughts separate from God, and his power, when tested, exposes the foolish.
verses.comment: God's power is not easily manipulated. Doubt and deception are barriers to true fellowship with Him, as the Epistle of James teaches.

verses.text: Wisdom will not enter a soul that plots evil, nor dwell in a body enslaved by sin.
verses.comment: A connection between purity and communion with God's Spirit. The body is a temple, and spiritual life requires moral uprightness, seen in 1 Cor. 6:19.

verses.text: For the holy spirit of instruction flees deceit, withdraws from foolish thoughts, and is driven away when unrighteousness comes in.
verses.comment: This highlights the personal nature of God's Spirit, a theme fulfilled in the promise of the Holy Spirit in the New Testament.

verses.text: Wisdom is a spirit that loves people, but she will not excuse a blasphemer for his words, for God is a witness of his inmost thoughts, a true observer of his heart, and hears his tongue.
verses.comment: The all-encompassing knowledge of God is evident, as seen in Psalms. Wisdom’s role reflects the feminine imagery present in Proverbs and the God-given gift of understanding.

verses.text: For the Spirit of the Lord fills the world, and that which holds all things together has knowledge of every word spoken.
verses.comment: Affirms God's omnipresence and the sustaining power of His Spirit, themes found in both Psalms and Acts. Shows that creation is held together by God's constant action, pointing to divine providence.

verses.text: Therefore no one who speaks unjustly will go unnoticed, nor will justice pass him by.
verses.comment: God’s justice ensures accountability. The themes of judgment and moral responsibility connect Old and New Testament teaching.

verses.text: For the plans of the ungodly will be examined, and the sound of his words will reach the Lord for punishment of his lawless deeds.
verses.comment: This passage warns that secret sins and thoughts receive divine attention, reinforcing God’s intimate knowledge and perfect justice.

verses.text: For a jealous ear hears all things, and the noise of murmuring will not be hidden.
verses.comment: Emphasizes God’s perfect attention, even to secret grievances. Reinforces the importance of sincere speech and thought.

verses.text: So beware of useless grumbling, and restrain your tongue from slandering. Even what is said in secret will not go unpunished, and a lying mouth leads to death.
verses.comment: The moral implications of speech—life and death—are common in Proverbs and the teachings of Jesus. Points to the spiritual and eternal consequences of the tongue.

verses.text: Do not aim for death by wandering astray, nor bring destruction upon yourself by the works of your hands.
verses.comment: Both choices and deeds have spiritual consequences. There is a precedent for this idea in Jeremiah and in Jesus’ teaching about the narrow path.

verses.text: For God did not create death, nor does he delight in the destruction of the living.
verses.comment: Imparts that death entered through sin, not by God’s design, reflecting themes from Genesis and Jesus’s triumph over death.

verses.text: For he created all things so they might exist, and the creatures of the world are wholesome; there is no deadly poison in them, and the realm of death does not rule on earth.
verses.comment: God’s goodness in creation is stressed, echoing Genesis. The world, though fallen, is fundamentally made for life, not death.
Points to the eternal life of those who walk with God, a rising theme fulfilled in Christ through resurrection and immortal life.

verses.text: But the wicked summoned death by their words and actions, considering him their friend. They wasted away and made a covenant with death, because they are worthy to belong to him.
verses.comment: Sin’s effects are not just personal but also communal. Reference to a ‘covenant with death’ is echoed in Isaiah, and the wages of sin culminating in death is a key theme of the New Testament.
